customer_addr:
998 West Mission Bay Drive
San Diego, CA 92109

citations.narrative:
In the freezer used to store raw fish fed to the three harbor seals, a torn bag of exposed fish was identified. The fish had
visible freezer burn and were frozen into a solid block of ice which could result in contamination.
Failure to keep food for marine mammals free from contamination could negatively affect the animals and lead to potential
disease.
The facility must ensure that food for marine mammals must be wholesome, palatable, and free from contamination.
Correct by 19 July 2024

There was a plastic water bottle and a black hair tie in the primary enclosure of three harbor seals. Exposure to trash and
debris can pose a health and disease hazard to marine mammals.
Particulate animal and food waste, trash, or debris that enters the primary enclosure must be removed at least daily, or as
often as necessary, to maintain the required water quality and to minimize health and disease hazards to the marine
mammals. A facility employee immediately removed the debris from the primary enclosure.
Corrected at time of inspection
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representative.
Additional Inspectors:
Eric Irvin, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER
Ronald Richardson, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
3.105(a) 
   
Feeding. 
In the freezer used to store raw fish fed to the three harbor seals, a torn bag of exposed fish was identified. The fish had 
visible freezer burn and were frozen into a solid block of ice which could result in contamination.  
Failure to keep food for marine mammals free from contamination could negatively affect the animals and lead to potential 
disease.  
The facility must ensure that food for marine mammals must be wholesome, palatable, and free from contamination.  
Correct by 19 July 2024 
3.107(a)(2) 
   
Sanitation 
There was a plastic water bottle and a black hair tie in the primary enclosure of three harbor seals. Exposure to trash and 
debris can pose a health and disease hazard to marine mammals.  
Particulate animal and food waste, trash, or debris that enters the primary enclosure must be removed at least daily, or as 
often as necessary, to maintain the required water quality and to minimize health and disease hazards to the marine 
mammals. A facility employee immediately removed the debris from the primary enclosure. 
Corrected at time of inspection 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representative. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
Eric Irvin, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER 
Ronald Richardson, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
